user_request: A poem about a road not taken and the difference it made.
final_poem:
# Two Roads, One Choosing

Where the path forks and the map is thin,
I stood at altitude, breath on my hands,
the creek below still doing what creeks understand—
running right through the place where I happened.

One trail descended into timber darkened
by a hundred years of no one's forgetting.
The other turned uphill, thin as a question,
and before me opened into country

where the air sat on the land like it owned it,
where a field stretched out without a fence,
where somewhere in that silence a door
had once been knocked shut clean enough to frame

the leaving—arched, domestic, every detail
a kitchen anyone could walk through, later.
I chose the narrow slope and lost the map.
I trusted where my foot had already stepped,

and that first step made all others possible,
not by overriding what was there but
by opening thinner corridors for light—
how a vein becomes a river's artery.

Years later: the difference showed not in wealth,
for both paths widened into ordinary width,
but in the way I hung my window open
toward whatever arrived without an appointment,

in how I let the afternoon keep me
instead of reading what someone said about it.
The unlived life, they warn you—oh, the pile
somewhere beneath the flower boxes,

but what I found was simpler: just the habit
of turning left where any other person
would've gone straight. And that small refusal
had made a country in my view of things,

a kind of keeping-past-doors-open, almost
superstitious, almost unlatching

what the body learned to lock.
I didn't find freedom—freedom is the price
we pay for choosing nothing. What I found
was more like having hands again after ice.

The creek below kept going where it must.
Mine kept going too, down different grasses,
slower, bordered now by stones I set myself,
each one a small commemoration

of the act of slowing—how the hand
learns slower than the mind understands
that stopping is not loss but the first
architecture, the lime in mortar,

the thing that holds the choosing open
so another choice can find its own edge.
I don't know which road was wrong. I suspect
both were right for someone else on them.

What I know: the version of me who took left
brought back a stone to keep beside my bed,
touching it and feeling something like
the whole slow weight of what I didn't leave behind.
